entry.title: Re: Re Print Customer Invoices in Mass
entry.content:
Hi @Dean_Wealleans  

Thank you for your question

Please note, to efficiently handle requests for multiple invoices within a time frame, against a statement, or for specific sales orders, you can use SAP transaction VF31 (Output Processing for Billing Documents). VF31 allows selection of multiple billing documents based on your criteria and supports mass reprinting or emailing of invoices.

Here is my suggested approach:

  • Enter the output type for invoice print or email.
  • Filter invoices by customer, date range, or related sales orders.
  • Execute and select all relevant invoices.
  • Trigger mass print or send by email.

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud or Fiori environments, similar functionality is available via the Print Invoice or Manage Billing Documents apps, or you can leverage the SAP Cloud Print Manager for bulk document processing.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

Mass Print of Invoices

How to print invoices in Mass?

entry.title: Re: Quantity Scales determination in the multi payee cond...
entry.content:
To drive your multi-payee scale determination on the total quantity‚Äîwhile still settling each payee on their individual volume‚Äîyou need to:

  • Transfer the aggregated total quantity into the settlement document
  • Base your scale routine on that transferred total quantity
  • Keep your settlement calculation itself on the individual volumes

With the below configuration pattern, it should work for you.

In SPRO navigate to Sales & Distribution ‚Üí Settlement Management ‚Üí Condition Contract ‚Üí Business Volume Profile. Open your profile, go to the Business Volume Selection Criteria tab. Add a new entry (or edit existing) for Total Business Volume Quantity: ‚Äì Business Volume Condition = RBVT (Total Business Volume) ‚Äì Transfer to Settlement = X ‚Äì Subtotal = 5. This flags that, on settlement, SAP must copy the sum of all volumes (qty) into the settlement document‚Äôs RBVT item.

In OPL8 (or COR4 ‚Üí Pricing Procedure) copy your base procedure (e.g. KZ0) to a Z-procedure. Insert RBVT as a condition type at Subtotal 5. Make sure your settlement condition (RES1 or your Z-equivalent) sits after RBVT.

On RES1 (or your Z-settlement type) set Scale Routine = 02 in condition‚Äìtype definition. Routine 02 reads the resident subtotal (RBVT at subtotal 5) and picks the correct scale break based on that. If your system release lacks routine 02 for quantities, copy it in VOFM ‚Üí Sizing Routines and adjust the table logic to handle KOMK-KNUME (quantity) instead of KOMK-KNUMH (amount).

You run settlement for your condition contract (0S02) ‚Üí system builds an SD billing‚Äêtype settlement doc. RBVT carries in the grand total qty across all payees. RES1‚Äôs scale‚Äêroutine 02 determines the scale break (e.g. 0‚Äì1,000 pcs ‚Üí 2%; 1,001‚Äì5,000 pcs ‚Üí 3%; etc.) based on that RBVT qty. Each individual line uses its own individual business volume to calculate its final rebate value (scale % √ó each payee qty).

entry.title: SuccessFactors LMS should automatically log completions once a class concludes.
entry.content:
Hello Everyone,
 
We are planning to implement a process where course completions are automatically recorded as soon as the course is finished. For VILT sessions, we understand that integration with a virtual platform can support this. However, for ILT/classroom trainings, instructors currently need to manually scan QR codes or badges using iPads to mark attendance, and then record completions manually‚Äîeither by the instructor or an admin.
We are looking to automate this entire process. To move forward, we would like to explore the available tools and solutions in the market that can support this need. Additionally, we are interested in identifying vendors who can assist in implementing this solution, with the requirement that the system must comply with USFDA standards, as we operate in the life sciences sector.
We would appreciate your insights, recommendations, or any experience you can share regarding potential tools or partners.
Note: Some customers use biometric systems to capture class completions, although we do not have visibility into the specific tools they are using. Others utilize the SAP BTP platform with web services for automation. We are currently exploring what additional solutions are available in the market beyond these two approaches.
#QRCode #Class attendance 
Regards,
Ashok

entry.title: Re: Certified PDF in VIM
entry.content:
Hi @TriptiKaushik 

Thank you for your question.

SAP VIM supports attaching multiple related documents to a single invoice, including image files (JPG) and PDF files such as certified PDFs. These attachments are linked in the invoice processing lifecycle and stored in the document archive using ArchiveLink or an integrated content management system.

To ensure the certified PDF is captured as an attachment, please confirm your inbound document channels and processing configurations correctly recognize and classify this file along with other invoice documents.

The below links provides you with real case scenario and a video guidance.

How to auto-generate PDF attachment to invoice

SAP Central Invoice Management - Receive invoices via E-mail

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

What does your backend interpret, or in what timezone is shown when using timestamps coming from your frontend?

Thomas

entry.title: Re: Custom Fiori app displays placeholder instead of actu...
entry.content:
@walkerist79 

SmartTable basically shows table columns based on UI annotations. You only need to specify the entitySet like the example below:

			<smartTable:SmartTable id="LineItemsSmartTable" entitySet="LineItemsSet" smartFilterId="smartFilterBar" tableType="Table" enableExport="true" beforeExport="onBeforeExport" useVariantManagement="true" useTablePersonalisation="true" header="Line Items" showRowCount="true" persistencyKey="SmartTableAnalytical_Explored" enableAutoBinding="true" class="sapUiResponsiveContentPadding" enableAutoColumnWidth="true" editTogglable="true" app:useSmartToggle="true">
				<!-- layout data used to make the table growing but the filter bar fixed -->
				<smartTable:layoutData>
					<FlexItemData growFactor="1" baseSize="0%"/>
				</smartTable:layoutData>
			</smartTable:SmartTable>

entry.title: DB2 11.5 LUW - HADR rebuild from online backup ?
entry.content:
Hello,

I am currently upgrading an IBM AIX OS based DB2 system. It was DB2 V9.7 at the start and therfore requires the HADR configuration to be rebuilt based on the IBM DB2 upgrade documentation on the process. 

The SAP ERP EHP5 database is 10TB in size , therefore a significant amount of time would be required to take an offline backup to the shared storage and then use that backup to rebuild the HACMP secondary database.

I've been searching the last few days on the possibility of using an online backup of the production primary database to avoid extended downtime, but almost all the hits I've found indicate offline backup is used. I found very few with online, but these posts looked like a small test type database was used for the example. 

Has anyone got any pointers on the best way to build a heavily used productive ERP DB2 HADR primary to the secondary with an online backup - or will the offline be the way - keeping the primary production SAP system down untill the HADR starts are done after the restore completes on the secondary HADR host.

Regards,

Brian.

entry.title: Re: Date Time as a Custom Filter Field
entry.content:
Hi Thomas,

Let me give you an example of my problem.

Let‚Äôs say I have a filter field on the List Report page of my application named "Start Date Time", which accepts date-time input from the user. Now, when I select a date like 2025-08-07 00:00:00, the actual value sent in the OData request is:

 

$filter=startDateTime eq 2025-08-06T18:30:00.000Z

This happens because I'm in the IST timezone (UTC+5:30), and the browser automatically adjusts the time to UTC when sending the request.

However, my backend service expects the value to be in UTC without any timezone offset manipulation ‚Äî it expects exactly 2025-08-07T00:00:00Z.

So this mismatch leads to incorrect filtering of records because the time shifted by 5.5 hours causes the backend to fetch results for the previous day.

What I want:

I‚Äôd like to override the behavior of the filter bar such that when the user selects a date and time, it is converted to UTC manually and sent exactly in the expected format ‚Äî like 2025-08-07T00:00:00Z.
You can connect me in Teams (gagan.prajapati@sap.com)
Thanks,
Gagan

  loop at t_return into e_return.

    if  e_return-type   eq 'S'

entry.title: Re: SD: Rounding differences in invoicing
entry.content:
Even though 35 000 √ó 9 % = 3 150.00 exactly, SAP SD can still show 3 149.98 on each item when creating the invoice. This is by design, not a system bug, and is caused by how SAP rounds ‚Äúgroup‚Äù vs. ‚Äúitem‚Äù conditions and distributes header-level values to line items.

What is happening in your cause is that

  • You‚Äôve got a surcharge condition type (say, ZA09) that‚Äôs marked as both an item and group condition in V/06.
  • At item processing, SAP calculates the surcharge per line: ‚Äì 35 000.00 √ó 9 % = 3 150.00 ‚ûî rounded to 2 decimals = 3 150.00
  • Because it‚Äôs a group condition, SAP then: ‚Äì Adds up all line net values (6 √ó 35 000 = 210 000), calculates 210 000 √ó 9 % = 18 900.00 ‚Äì Distributes that 18 900.00 back to the 6 lines ‚Äì During distribution the system must split and round each share (18 900.00 √∑ 6 = 3 150.00, but distribution logic yields 3 149.98 on most lines and 3 150.12 on one line)
  • The first time you look at the item lines, you see the pure item-level 3 150.00. But once you enter the header conditions, SAP re-runs the group calculation & distribution, so your items jump to the ‚Äúdistributed‚Äù values (3 149.98) and the tiny rounding variance shows up.

If you don‚Äôt need header-level distribution, simply uncheck Group Condition on your surcharge in V/06. Now every line is calculated and rounded in isolation‚Äîno distribution, no variance.

SAP Note 80183 describes ways to minimize rounding variances by using formula routines 919/920 on all pre-net discount/surcharge conditions, ensuring SAP rounds at the point you choose (item vs. header) Follow the note‚Äôs ‚ÄúVariant 2‚Äù or ‚ÄúVariant 3‚Äù recommendations if you have complex multi-condition pricing.

entry.title: Re: Why does admin.eu1.gigya.com point to US1 load balancer?
entry.content:
Hi @alemasetto ,

All Admin endpoints are routed through us1 data center, which has always been the main data center for these services. This setup has been in place since the beginning and it makes sense since us1 is the primary hub in the au1-eu1-us1 cluster, so having the endpoints served from the ‚Äúmaster‚Äù location ensures stability and consistency.

Also worth noting:
Admin endpoints don‚Äôt interact with personal account data, so there‚Äôs no conflict with GDPR compliance. Everything‚Äôs designed with privacy and security in mind. 

Hope this is helpful.

Regards,
Anand Raj

entry.title: Navigation Issue in CAP UI5 Apps on BTP CF Fiori Launchpad After Page Refresh
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are building several CAP-based UI5 applications deployed on BTP Cloud Foundry.

When these applications run inside the Fiori Launchpad (FLP), we encounter a navigation issue: if a user refreshes the page explicitly, they are unable to navigate back using either the browser‚Äôs back button or the Launchpad‚Äôs NavBack button (next to the SAP home icon). Initially, the user remains stuck on the current page (the browser hash doesn‚Äôt change either). After a few clicks, they are suddenly redirected straight to the FLP home page.

There are no errors/warnings/info in the browser's console log.

This issue does not occur when the same UI5 apps are run in standalone mode (accessed via the HTML5 Applications tab in the BTP Cockpit), nor does it affect Fiori Elements apps running in FLP.

Here‚Äôs how we handle navigation and routing in our UI5 app view controllers (TypeScript):

Navigating Forward

// params are routing parameters such as mandatory parameter
public navToView(viewName: string, params?: object): void {
    this.getRouter().navTo(viewName, params ? params : {});
}

Example usage:

public onNavToNextView(): void {
    this.navToView("nextView");
}

We even added a nav back button, but it has the same problem as well.

Navigating Back

// same, params is just an obj for routing parameters
public navBackToView(viewName: string, params?: object): void {
    const history = History.getInstance();
    const previousHash = history.getPreviousHash();

    if (previousHash !== undefined) {
        window.history.go(-1);
    } else {
        this.getRouter().navTo(viewName, params ? params : {}, true);
    }
}

Example usage:

// press event for nav back button
public onNavBack(): void {
    this.navBackToView("previousView");
}

This is how we initialise the router in the Component.ts file:

this.getRouter().initialize();

This is the routing configuration in the manifest.json file:

"routing": {
      "config": {
        "routerClass": "sap.m.routing.Router",
        "controlAggregation": "pages",
        "controlId": "app",
        "transition": "slide",
        "type": "View",
        "viewType": "XML",
        "path": "myapp.view",
        "async": true,
        "bypassed": {
          "target": "notFound"
        }
      },
      "routes": [
        {
          "name": "RouteHome",
          "pattern": ":?query:",
          "target": ["TargetHome"]
        },
        {
          "pattern": "login",
          "name": "login",
          "target": "login"
        }
      ],
      "targets": {
        "TargetHome": {
          "id": "Home",
          "name": "Home",
          "level": 1
        },
        "login": {
          "viewName": "Login",
          "viewId": "login",
          "level": 1
        },
        "notFound": {
          "id": "notFound",
          "name": "NotFound",
          "transition": "show"
        }
      }
    }

 

Are we missing something in our implementation? We‚Äôve followed UI5 examples from the Demo Kit. Could this be a known or unknown issue/bug with FLP itself?

Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you.

entry.title: Re: EF5008 No special G/L acct defined for acct type D sp...
entry.content:
When you post a down-payment via F-29, SAP uses your customizing in FBKP/OBXR to look up the correct vendor‚Äêreconciliation (down-payment) G/L account automatically. However, with BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST, the BAPI doesn‚Äôt always call the same ‚Äúpick‚Äêup‚Äù logic‚Äîunless you explicitly provide either:

  • The special G/L reconciliation account in your BAPI‚Äêinput tables, or
  • The correct customizing entries that the BAPI actually reads.

If neither is found, you get the error - No special G/L acct defined for acct type D sp.G/L ind. A recon.acct (Message F5 008)

In FBKP, set up Offsetting entries in Special G/L transactions for Account Type = D (Vendor), Special G/L Indicator = A (Down Payment) and enter your vendor‚Äêreconcil. account here.

The other alternate is Alternate reconciliation via OBXR. In OBXR, ensure your Special G/L indicator A is mapped to the correct reconciliation account for each vendor‚Äêaccount group or company code. This is the fallback the standard GUI uses‚ÄîBAPI only reads OBXR if you leave the recon‚Äêaccount blank in your input. If either FBKP or OBXR customizing is missing or incomplete, F-29 will still work (it can pull from the vendor master), but the BAPI will choke.

So in summary, to fix your issue,
ensure FBKP/OBXR Customizing where you have to define the down‚Äêpayment reconcil. G/L account for Account Type D & Indicator A.
populate or override via BAPI where you need to include RECON_ACCOUNT in your ACCOUNTRECEIVABLE/PAYABLE table and mark it in the X‚Äêstructure.

entry.title: Re: Transport the service Catalogue Issue
entry.content: It seems you're having trouble creating a transport for the C_GLACCOUNTHIERARCHYNODE_SRV service in transaction /n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE, even after accepting the standard warning message. The most likely cause is a missing authorization or an issue with your system's transport configuration (STMS). You should ask your Basis team to verify that your user has the necessary permissions to create transport requests and that your system has a valid transport route configured. This will likely resolve the issue by enabling the pop-up where you can assign the service to a transport.

entry.title: Re: Unify ECC and NetWeaver HCM during the S/4HANA conver...
entry.content:
Hello Anderson,

 

If you want to unify two systems into one, the recommended approach is selective data transition. You can choose to do this either all at once or step by step. For example, you could first convert your ECC system to SAP S/4HANA, and then selectively move your HCM system into the new SAP S/4HANA.

To learn more about this transition path, please review this information: https://support.sap.com/en/offerings-programs/support-services/data-management-landscape-transformation/selective-data-transition-engagement.html

 

Regards,

Jose M.

entry.title: ‚ÄãAdvanced Developing Skills to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management
entry.content:
Chapter 1: Define the Purpose 

This guide helps Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition partners and customers to build custom mobile applications by integrating the Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) with SAP Build Code. 

Previously, we published a step-by-step guide blog detailing the development process for a sample mobile application.
ÔºàA Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build CodeÔºöhttps://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/a-step-by-step-guide-to-build-a-custom-mobile-apps-for-warehouse-management/ba-p/14155800Ôºâ

This follow-up article will highlight key features and advantages of the SAP Build Code-Mobile Develop Kit that enhance development, including: 

  • Use the built-in "Actions" to quickly generate a REST request. 
  • Debugging methods for mobile applications. 
  • Joule AI co-development, with examples of automated code assistance to accelerate the development process. 

 

Chapter 2: Use Actions with JavaScript 

This chapter introduces key points for using Actions to create and send a REST request. Actions are a set of built-in instructions in SAP Build Code. They enable you to control mobile application behaviors such as navigation, messaging, document opening, and other behaviors using visual no-code or low-code methods. Additionally, they support generating instructions for sending requests via REST services. For a detailed tutorial, you can refer to this guide. 

SendRequest - Mobile Development Kit References 
Step to create a REST Action: 

1.Right-click the Actions folder in the file directory of the project and select "MDK: New Action". 

 2. Choose "REST Service Send Request" and click "Next". 

 3. You can configure your service URL and additional properties here. "Success Action" and "Failure Action" refer to the actions to be taken after the request succeeds or fails, respectively. 

 4. The obtained result can be retrieved via‚ÄØactionBinding, and further operations can be performed on it. 
Using example in previous Blog: ÔºàA Step-by-Step Guide to Build a Custom Mobile Apps for Warehouse Management Using SAP Build CodeÔºöhttps://community.sap.com/t5/supply-chain-management-blog-posts-by-sap/a-step-by-step-guide-to-build-a-custom-mobile-apps-for-warehouse-management/ba-p/14155800Ôºâ

Set the "Target" of the action to the rest request for getting warehousetaskÔºö 

{{TestServerURL}}/sap/opu/odata4/sap/api_warehouse_order_task_2/srvd_a2x/sap/warehouseorder/0001 

Then the returned warehousetask information will be as shown in the figure below.  

 

Next, we can create a Rule use the following example code. 

Example code: 

export default function ShowWarehouseTask(clientAPI) { 

‚ÄØ alert(JSON.stringify(clientAPI.getActionBinding())); 

}

Last step, bind the "Success Action" of the send request action to this rule file. This means that if the request returns a success, this successful rule will be triggered. We can then bind this action to the button on the page and click it to trigger it (for specific methods, refer to the previous blog).

 

 

Chapter 3: Tracing API Request in Mobile App 

For tracing request and returned information sent in mobile app. 

1. Open the mobile service on the storyboard, which can be found in Quick Access. 

 2. Scroll down to the bottom of the "Add on Features" section. If the "Network Trace" option is not visible, click the nearby "Add Feature" button to enable it. 

 3. After clicking ‚Äã‚Äã"Start Recording"‚Äã‚Äã, use the mobile app to send requests. The log will capture all network requests. After downloading the ‚Äã‚Äãrecording‚Äã‚Äã, view the request status, response values, and other details ‚Äã‚Äãto analyze the issue‚Äã‚Äã. 

 

 

Chapter 4: Joule Example: Using Joule AI to Accelerate Development 

Joule AI integrated into this web-based compiler enhances rapid development. 

However, ‚Äã‚Äãfor complex actions‚Äã‚Äã, its generated code may lack precision or executability, requiring manual inspection and refinement. ‚Äã‚ÄãFor simpler actions and UIs‚Äã‚Äã, Joule significantly accelerates development‚Äî‚Äã‚Äãthe clearer your language descriptions‚Äã‚Äã, ‚Äã‚Äãthe more tailored content Joule generates‚Äã‚Äã. 

‚Äã‚ÄãKey commonly used commands include:‚Äã 

1. /mdk-gen-action 
Automatically generates action configurations and embeds them into mobile service files. These actions can be bound to UI elements (e.g., buttons) to trigger workflows‚Äîsuch as navigation, message prompts, or REST API calls (e.g., GET/POST). 

2. /mdk-gen-page 
Generates UI pages based on OData entity metadata or custom requirements. 

You may also use /help to discover other available features.  

 

‚ÄãUsage Example‚Äã‚Äã: Taking the use of the Cancel Warehouse Task Request in the WOWT API as an example, we need to use the Joule function to generate action code and UI interfaces. 

Input in JouleÔºö 

"I need a 'send request' action to send a POST request to:   

{{starturl}}/sap/opu/odata4/.../WarehouseTask(   

  EWMWarehouse='{{whse}}',   

  WarehouseTask='{{wt}}',   

  WarehouseTaskItem='{{wt_item}}'   

)/SAP__self.CancelWarehouseTask?sap-client={{client}}   

Headers:   

- If-Match: *   

- X-CSRF-Token: {{csrf_token}}"

 

For UI Creation: 

/mdk-gen-page #your_service  

"Generate a form page with:   

Text input fields for:   

   - Warehouse Task ID   

   - Warehouse Item ID   

   - Warehouse Location   

A confirmation button labeled 'Cancel Task'"

Output: 

Next, you only need to make simple modifications to quickly generate a cancel warehouse task request page. 

 

 

Conclusion   

This guide introduces some advanced usage methods of SAP Build Code as well as distinctive tools that are different from those in other development approaches, etc. The main content includes: 

  • Using built-in tools "Actions" to simplify REST API integration. 
  • Debugging network requests directly in the app. 
  • Leveraging Joule AI to speed up basic code and UI creation. 

It is hoped that these advanced methods can be helpful to you when developing mobile apps for our API in Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

 

Referenced Data and Additional Training Lessons 

Warehouse Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API 
Warehouse Task and Warehouse Order (A2X) API (from SAP Business Accelerator Hub) 

 

Official tutorial web for mobile development kit clients. 

SAP Tutorial Navigator | Tutorials for SAP Developers 

 

Explore the mobile development kit SDK and build a custom Android/iOS client, enable push notifications, and create extensions. 

Brand Your Customized App with Mobile Development Kit SDK | SAP Tutorials 

 

Customize the look and feel of your MDK app with extension controls using metadata approach or Native script plugins. 

Create Extension Controls in Mobile Development Kit (MDK) Apps | SAP Tutorials

entry.title: Unlocking On-Premise Data for SAP Joule Studio with SAP BTP Destinations
entry.content:
1 ‚Äì Why this matters

Since July 2025, Joule Studio has supported SAP BTP Destination service as a first-class data source. In practice, that means you can point the copilot to any on-premise or partner API that is exposed through a Destination, without replicating data to the cloud. Joule then consumes the data securely at runtime, treats it just like a native Skill, and returns answers in natural language. 
https://architecture.learning.sap.com/docs/ref-arch/06ff6062dc

For the many customers who still run SAP ECC, S/4HANA On-Premise, or tightly-regulated third-party systems, this closes the one remaining gap: Joule‚Äôs AI smarts are now reachable before a full RISE-with-SAP migration. You still need a Joule client, from SAP Build WorkZone, for example.

 

2 ‚Äì How the plumbing works

  1. Set up SAP Cloud Connector

    Create an outbound tunnel from your DMZ to the BTP subaccount and whitelist the internal host and port. No inbound firewall holes are necessary.

  2. Define a Destination

    In BTP, configure a Destination with ProxyType = OnPremise that points to the internal OData, REST or RFC endpoint. Add OAuth2 SAML-Bearer, Basic, or principal propagation as required.

  3. Import in Joule Studio

    In the new ‚ÄúData Services‚Äù tab, choose Import from Destination. Joule Studio inspects the OpenAPI spec or $metadata document and generates an Action (Skill) interface automatically.

Run the chat

At runtime, Joule resolves the Destination, routes the call through Cloud Connector, and grounds the LLM‚Äôs answer on live on-prem data. Authorizations remain intact because Joule forwards the user‚Äôs JWT or system credentials.

Note: You still need to wrap legacy RFC/BAPI calls in OData V2, CAP or RAP facades so that Destinations can expose them cleanly.

 

3 ‚Äì Three concrete scenarios for FR & BE customers

Scenario 1 ‚Äì Luxury retailer in France (ECC6 + BW on HANA)

A store manager types: ‚ÄúStock du sac ‚ÄòMontpellier‚Äô au Printemps Haussmann ?‚Äù Joule calls BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST through the Destination and replies in French within seconds, eliminating phone calls and SAP GUI look-ups during peak tourist season.

Scenario 2 ‚Äì Belgian discrete manufacturer (S/4HANA OP 2021 FPS02)

An engineer asks: ‚ÄúMontre-moi les cinq derniers r√©sultats QC pour le lot 450123.‚Äù Joule fetches data from the QA32 OData service, surfaces inspection characteristics and links to the certificate of analysis PDF, cutting lead time on corrective actions required by EU MDR regulations.

Scenario 3 ‚Äì Cross-border energy utility (FR/BE) with third-party DMS + ECC

A field technician on an ATEX-rated iPad says: ‚ÄúQuelle est la proc√©dure de purge pour la vanne 14-BE-125 ?‚Äù Joule simultaneously queries a Documentum REST API for technical drawings and the ECC equipment master via two Destinations, providing hands-free access and reducing pipeline downtime.

 

 

4 ‚Äì Getting started

  1. Upgrade your Joule Studio tenant to the July 2025 feature bundle (or later).

  2. Patch Cloud Connector 2.17 or newer to enable JWT forwarding.

  3. Model an on-prem API fa√ßade (CAP, RAP, SAP Gateway) and expose a $metadata endpoint.

  4. Create design-time and runtime Destinations, setting WebIDEEnabled = true.

  5. Import, test and publish the new Skill inside Joule Studio.

  6. Roll out to pilot users, collect unanswered questions and refine the Skill.

     

5 ‚Äì Why this is a big deal

  • It bridges the last mile for hybrid landscapes: on-prem data stays on-prem, yet Joule can reach it securely.

  • It eases cloud adoption: start with one high-impact use case, prove value, and migrate workloads at your own pace.

  • It reduces change management: users keep one chat UI while the back-end location is abstracted away.

  • It is future-proof: the same Destination can later point to your RISE system with minimal refactoring.

Yes, some development effort is still required (especially to wrap legacy BAPIs and secure tokens) but the payoff in faster decisions and higher user satisfaction is already evident among early adopters.

Happy building, and let Joule talk to all your data! üöÄ

entry.title: Re: Issue with Automatic Inspection plan assignment to in...
entry.content:
When you have multiple inspection plans (group counters) for the same material with the same Usage, SAP‚Äôs standard auto‚Äêassignment logic for GR (Usage 04) only looks at

  • the task list group (from the material master),
  • the Usage code, and
  • the material‚Äâ/‚Äâplant assignments in each plan.

It does not factor in Vendor for Usage 04. So when two plans both have Usage 04 and are assigned to the same material‚Äâ/‚Äâplant, the system simply picks the lowest group counter (GC 1) every time‚Äîeven if you restricted one plan to Vendor 2 in QP02.

Below are couple of options:

  1. Manual Selection via CRTD Status. Configure both plans with the same Usage. When MIGO posts GR, the lot will go to CRTD (Created) instead of REL (Released) if multiple valid group counters exist. User must then manually choose GC 1 or GC 2 in QA01/QA02. No coding change needed; only a process tweak.
  2. Differentiate by Usage Code. Give GC 1 Usage 04 (Goods Receipt) and GC 2 a custom Usage (e.g., Z4). Vendor 1 lots pick Usage 04 ‚Üí GC 1. Vendor 2 lots won‚Äôt auto‚Äêassign (no Z4 usage for GR)‚Äîthey land in CRTD and you pick manually (or build logic to auto‚Äêrelease). Works without enhancement but complicates Usage management.
  3. Use a Quality Info Record. Create a Q‚ÄêInfo record (transaction QP13/QP21) for Material + Vendor 2 and assign GC 2 in it. Standard QM logic will check for a vendor-specific info record before falling back to task list‚Äêgroup logic. Lots from Vendor 2 then pick GC 2 automatically.
  4. Add Custom Logic via User-Exit or BAdI. Implement the BAdI /QM/QPL_PLAN_DETERM (or the classic user-exit in function module QP_SELECT_INSPECTION_PLAN) to inject Vendor into the selection criteria. In your routine, read the purchase order‚Äôs vendor (from the inspection‚Äêlot source data) and choose GC 2 when it matches Vendor 2, otherwise GC 1. Fully automated and rules-driven; requires ABAP.

Recommended approaches are

  • If you need truly seamless GR‚Äêtime plan assignment by vendor, the Quality Info Record route (Option 3) is the least invasive‚Äîno ABAP, no custom Usage codes, and it piggybacks on standard QM master-data precedence logic.
  • If you already have many materials and prefer a code-based rule (for example, you‚Äôll roll out more vendor-specific plans later), go with Option 4 and implement the QM BAdI for inspection plan determination.

Also have a look at SAP Note 487539

entry.title: Re: Condition Types in Purchase Orders and Contracts (Hea...
entry.content:
Hello @Shubham120798 

Thank you for your detailed feedback and for raising these important clarifications regarding condition types in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud for Procurement.

Here‚Äôs a summary addressing your points:

Purchasing Condition Types in S/4HANA Public Cloud:
You are correct: the standard delivered condition types for Purchasing (MM) are distinct from those used in Sales (SD). In S/4HANA Public Cloud, you will find purchasing-specific condition types such as DL01 (Delivery Costs), DRN1 (Discount), DRQ1 (Quantity Discount), DPR2 (Document/PO Header Discount), FGW1 (Freight), PB00 (Gross Price), and more. These are maintained within the cloud solution and available for use in purchasing documents such as purchase orders and contracts.

Header- vs. Item-Level Condition Types:

  • Condition types like DPR2 are configured for use at the document header level, so they can be entered for the entire PO or contract.
  • Types such as DL01, DRN1, DRQ1, FGW1, and PB00 are item-level, applying to individual purchase order line items.
  • The assignment (header vs. item) is defined in configuration and cannot overlap for a single condition type.

Customization and Hiding of Condition Types:

  • Only those condition types included in the active purchasing calculation schema (pricing procedure) for a particular document type will appear in the UI; all others are effectively hidden from end users.
  • While you cannot "hide" SAP standard condition types globally via SSCUIs, you have full control over which appear by configuring your calculation schema through tools like SSCUI 101095 (Set Calculation Schema ‚Äì Purchasing).
  • You may also create custom condition types to suit unique requirements.

Pricing Procedure Flexibility:

  • The pricing procedure (calculation schema) in S/4HANA Public Cloud is editable within the available cloud configuration options. This allows you to add or remove standard and custom condition types, or adjust their order and calculation logic, as permitted by SAP‚Äôs fit-to-standard cloud principles.

Summary:

  • The system provides a standard set of MM-specific condition types, with clear options for header and item assignment.
  • You control which condition types are active via your calculation schema configuration.
  • Pricing procedures are not fixed in Public Cloud; you can adapt them to your procurement business needs within SAP‚Äôs best-practice framework.

Condition Type for Pricing in Purchasing ‚Äì Read-SAP Help

Pricing and Conditions-SAP help 

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Including @OData.publish:true on v4 OData service.
entry.content:
No.

@odata.publish is an older altenative to create OData services (it only works with OData V2).

It was created even before the existance of RAP, service definitions and bindings and most likely even before OData V4 was officially released. 

In other words, it was never a pre-requisite. Just do not use it if you go with service definition + binding.

You can still use it for whatever reason - the system will not complain about using it + using the same CDS in a service definition but it's definitely not needed and makes things confusing.

entry.title: Re: Dynamic Text box
entry.content:
Hello @Carvalho_A1 

Thank you for your inquiry regarding the setup of fiscal year variants (FYV) for SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

You can indeed create a custom Fiscal Year Variant to accommodate non-standard quarters such as December to February, March to May, and so forth, tailored to your reporting requirements. This is done by copying the standard quarterly variant QT and adjusting the period start and end dates as needed.

How to proceed:

  • Use the app Define Fiscal Year Variants (SSCUI 102447) in your SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud tenant.
  • Copy the standard variant QT and configure your custom quarters (periods).
  • Ensure the variant has the appropriate number of posting periods.
  • Assign this custom fiscal year variant in your DRC report configuration under the ‚ÄúFiscal Year Variant‚Äù field.

For detailed guidance, please refer to the official SAP Help Portal documentation for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud here:
Define Your Own Fiscal Year Variant - SAP Help Portal

With regards

Chuma
